awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Sociocultural Dimensions of New Biometric Security Infrastructures
awd_abstract_narration:
What is the impact of the expanding role of technology in our social and political lives today? The increasing ubiquity of certain technological objects, specifically in the form of proliferating interfaces, is immediately observable. However, identification and security technologies such as biometrics and even mundane forms like electronic databases are more opaque to us. This project, which trains a graduate student in how to conduct rigorous, empirically grounded scientific fieldwork, will use scientific fieldwork-based methods to examine one of the most salient features of modern life today: large-scale, networked databases. Given heightening security concerns, in relation to the United States and its global affairs, it is crucial to investigate how databased identification technologies intersect with security and governance practices. This project will develop an empirical understanding of security infrastructures; it asks how they percolate into social domains such as kinship, migration, commerce, and dwelling practices, shaping aspects of ordinary life seemingly far outside the purview of security. It will enhance understandings of the social and political implications of security practices as they bear upon public policy, social and geopolitical relations. Thus, it will facilitate the development of programs and policies in order to produce secure yet equitable social environments. In addition to providing funding for the training of a graduate student in anthropology, findings will be disseminated to organizations and individuals that explore and manage the causes, consequences, and complexities of security practices.

Zehra Hashmi, under the supervision of Dr. Matthew Hull of the University of Michigan, will explore the relationship between new security infrastructures, kinship, and social organization. This research focuses on one of the pioneers in national biometric identification: Pakistan's National Database and Registration Authority (NADRA), and manner and means in which it shapes domains of everyday social life. NADRA's significance lies in its ubiquity: the card is used for banking, paying bills, school admissions, acquiring a cell phone chip, property transactions and voting. Key actors involved in NADRA operations are algorithms that integrate and verify data, particularly familial relations creating kin units. This research will analyze how NADRA reconstitutes kin ties by studying its effects on Pashtun migrants in Islamabad, for whom the identity card is a central preoccupation. Through multi-sited ethnographic fieldwork in Pashtun neighborhoods and NADRA's institutional sites, this research asks how NADRA's identification processes shape conceptions of security in a more generalizable manner. This study will collect data on how NADRA informs claims and experiences of urban space, especially for the ethnically marginalized. Further, it will investigate how NADRA itself is shaped by citizens, and what this reveals about governance and security practices. Thus, this study will illuminate connections between databases, security practices, and the status of ethnic minorities as they crystalize into a single, state-organized information infrastructure. This holds broad comparative implications and generalizable insights for the growing role of biometric, information and surveillance technologies for governance elsewhere on the globe, particularly the United States.

por.por_cntn:
My research project sought to identify and examine how the National Database and Registration Authority (NADRA)—a techno-bureaucratic entity that produces Pakistan’s biometric based identity card—moves from a security-oriented biometric identification system into a broader regulatory regime shaping domains of social life outside the realm of security, such as kinship and dwelling practices. Instead of assuming the impact of security or biometric identification technology, I examined both how a state security infrastructure is organized and how it is transformed by the practices of those who move through it. Thus, I combined archival and ethnographic methods, across multiple field sites, in order to answer my central research question. 

My first set of findings relate to the role of biometric technology for governance. Biometrics emphasize the significance of unique, bodily characteristics to determine identity. By deploying the body as a means to not just authenticate identity but also to speak over and against persons, biometrics are rendered unique arbiters of identity. Following NADRA’s practices reveals otherwise, through its reliance on kinship networks and genealogical documentation. In my dissertation, I hope to demonstrate that biometric technologies, along with the databases they rely on and produce, are necessarily “kinned” to perform their very function. That is, identification technologies, which appear to focus on the individual, are able to perform their governance functions by deploying and shaping social, particularly kin, relations. In relying upon relatedness, identification practices are themselves compelled to adapt to local conditions and demands, be they moral, legal or religious. Hence, ethnographic research enables insight into how increasingly pervasive biometric technologies operate and function in everyday social life, beyond how they are theorized or planned.

Secondly, by closely attending to ongoing processes of identity verification from the perspectives of migrants in Islamabad, while situated in their neighbourhood, I was able to track the constantly changing social and kinship dynamics and how this in turn impact identification procedures. Thus, I found that it was not only NADRA that shaped kin relations. Rather, the lived reality and practices of kinship amongst Pashtun migrants shaped the “data” that NADRA acquired and by extension the database it generated.

While conducting fieldwork at NADRA sites and these neighbourhoods, I also became attentive to the role of genealogical documentation. I found that often these documents entailed other forms of “identification”, broadly conceived. I aimed to situate the identity document within a historical context, and locate shifts in identification practices. Further, I hoped to understand the relationship between kin genealogies and the identification of individuals. In what ways was group identity a means to identify the individual? Through archival research at the National Archives in Pakistan and the British Library, I was able to identify the historical and political moments crucial for the question of individual identity, particularly in relation to governance and citizenship. In writing the historical component of my dissertation, I hope to bring colonial and postcolonial administrative documents in conversation with one another. Thus, I intend for historical material to serve more than just background and assist me in making a larger argument about historical change in governance and the implications this holds for who is seen as a citizen.   

Combining archival and ethnographic methods has enabled me to see both kinds of research materials in a different light; I was able to consider the nature of emergent social relations as they connected to historical factors, and ask different questions of my archival documents through what I found in the present. I was able to develop a comprehensive and rigorous understanding of the transition from empire to the postcolonial nation-state. Following from here, I was can trace changes, as administrative operations were reconfigured with the formation of new kinds of borders, as well as continuities in the ways that individual identification built upon processes of registration requiring one to demonstrate genealogical belonging. 

I participated in two public presentations in relation to my research while I was in Pakistan. At Quaid e Azam University in Islamabad, I presented my ethnographic material to help students consider how the identity card, built on a seemingly uniform system, may affect different identities and social positions. At the Lahore University of Management Sciences (LUMS), I participated in a panel with a human rights lawyer and a parliamentarian. The panel focused on the newly elected Prime Minister’s announcement that he would consider granting citizenship to Afghan refugees who had been born in Pakistan. In my discussion, I focused on the historically contingent meaning of citizenship, and the changing role of frontiers–multiple ones– in the process of considering what a “grant” of citizenship might entail. I found both these experiences rewarding and intellectually stimulating as they allowed me to engage with not only a scholarly community in Pakistan, but also a group with direct stakes in the issues raised by my research.
